results.content:
Stephen had a very methodical approach when explaining the different pieces of Meteor and React and how to make them work well together. I loved how, for each mini-project within the course, he deleted all the boilerplate code and wrote from the ground up. This method really helps when it comes to confidence and understanding of the writing code. Additionally, he spoke and taught in easy digestible tid bits that anyone could understand.

My one critique is that I wish he spoke a little more about the internals of Meteor and how certain aspects of the framework work. Meteor does a great deal for you as a developer and while that's awesome it's also dangerous. It becomes very easy to get caught up with memorizing certain techniques and when you don't understand enough about a system debugging becomes a nightmare.

Overall, great course. I would recommend it as a first choice to anyone thinking of using Meteor + React :D

results.content: This is *by far* my favorite class by Stephen (I've taken two of his other classes on Basic React with Redux, and Advanced React with Redux).  Stephen is a good instructor, and I feel like he is becoming a better instructor with each new course he publishes.  You might find at times that he repeats himself too many times, or sometimes stumbles over his words (and doesn't edit them out) but this has the added benefit of making him more human which makes me feel more confident that other people make mistakes while coding too.  At first the constant repeating was getting on my nerves - but it's much better in this course than his earlier courses.  I've taken other courses on meteor, but this is by far my most favorite.  It might leave you wanting for some extra details at times, and in some cases I think that Stephen doesn't know the absolute uber most best way to go about his MongoDB queries and how they can work well with Meteor - but for a introductory course this is absolutely fantastic.  It will help you feel comfortable starting out with meteor and react and get that part very solid.  Thanks Stephen for getting me there - I feel confident now that I can use meteor and react together!

You might find at times that he repeats himself too many times, or sometimes stumbles over his words (and doesn't edit them out) but this has the added benefit of making him more human which makes me feel more confident that other people make mistakes while coding too. At first the constant repeating was getting on my nerves - but it's much better in this course than his earlier courses. I've taken other courses on meteor, but this is by far my most favorite. It might leave you wanting for some extra details at times, and in some cases I think that Stephen doesn't know the absolute uber most best way to go about his MongoDB queries and how they can work well with Meteor - but for a introductory course this is absolutely fantastic. It will help you feel comfortable starting out with meteor and react and get that part very solid. Thanks Stephen for getting me there - I feel confident now that I can use meteor and react together!

results.content:
This was a fantastic course- Stephen does a great job communicating relevant items regarding Meteor & React. 

Unfortunately the curriculum is slightly outdated. While I was able to up to roughly 80% through doing (few) modifications to Stephen's code, I really had to back out when we reached React Router. It appears (which Stephen does allude too generally) the React Router v3 to v4 upgrade had considerable changes.
 
When trying to bring some elements from React Router into this curriculum I ran into a roadblock significant enough to disconnect me from the course. That being said, I'm absolutely not well versed in JavaScript or React, therefore someone with more experience learning specifically about interfacing with Meteor may have more luck.

Meteor does have further support for React which, thankfully, I learned some from Meteor's docs, giving me perhaps a slight advantage on building an app from Step 1. 

Without a doubt would be 5 stars if this course was updated!

results.content: This course covers all the basic parts of building a Meteor app with React, without skipping over some of the more complex stuff. The instructor's explanations were quite clear the entire time, so I didn't need to dig around a certain library's documentation to understand how and why something works the way it does. The fact that a beginner at web development like me had no trouble following through with everything speaks for itself (Meteor's backend development process might be easier than doing a lot of stuff manually with Node + Express, but there's still a stable amount of surprises here and there). I also found out about some very useful libraries that I'll probably use again at some point. And if you want to learn more about React apps (including Native), as well as Webpack (which can definitely help you optimize your work *a lot*), go check Stephen's other courses - they're among the best here on those subjects.
results.content_html: This course covers all the basic parts of building a Meteor app with React, without skipping over some of the more complex stuff. The instructor's explanations were quite clear the entire time, so I didn't need to dig around a certain library's documentation to understand how and why something works the way it does. The fact that a beginner at web development like me had no trouble following through with everything speaks for itself (Meteor's backend development process might be easier than doing a lot of stuff manually with Node + Express, but there's still a stable amount of surprises here and there). I also found out about some very useful libraries that I'll probably use again at some point. And if you want to learn more about React apps (including Native), as well as Webpack (which can definitely help you optimize your work *a lot*), go check Stephen's other courses - they're among the best here on those subjects.

results.content:
The course is clear concise and thorough.  I'll admit that at times it moves rather slowly, and it would seem to me that it could move faster.  After all, there are a lot of .js concepts in it that are accepted as understood by the viewer (most .js and .html basics).  As long as we're accepting that, it seems like we could cook through the components a little faster.

However, none of it prevented any significant reason to give anything less than a stellar review.  What I wanted, I got: how to write React/Meteor apps.  Meteor is evolving quickly (so is React for that matter).  Even though there are vibrant communities behind them, the docs out there leave a lot to be desired.  

At any rate, this was exactly what I needed -- a tutorial that assumed no prior knowledge of either the Meteor or React platforms.

results.content:
This is my second Meteor React course that I have completed on Udemy.  It helped me to understand certain points that I may have missed in the first tutorial. Mr. Grider has an excellent ability to explain difficult concepts and making them seem much simpler. He makes excellent use of diagrams to explain these concepts. 
However I may have been a little spoiled after completing the first tutorial, as it covered many other topics that this course glossed over. For some, glossing over these topics may be what they want, so the experience is subjective. Also it may need a little updating. 
Al in all, this course is really good and well worth taking.

results.content:
This course needs some updating:

All apps work, except the last one. Here's a list of the issues:

- the package 'react-codemirror' does not work properly with the current version of meteor/react. You need it for the last app you built in this course, which is really great! But the problem will be, if you use the old 'react-codemirror', that the live edit does not get updated in the codemirror field when working collaboratively on the same document. There is a new package called 'react-codemirror2', but to implement it, you'd have to do quite some investigation to get it working. This should be updated.

- The routing in react has changed significantly. I had to figure it out myself, in order to get the last application to work. Someone with less experience could get stuck here. To show you the difference, this is how its written in the course:

<Router history={browserHistory}>
        <Route path="/" component={App}>
            <Route path="bins" component={BinsMain} />
            ...
        </Route>
    </Router>

This is how I figured it out:

<BrowserRouter>
        <App>
            <Switch>
                <BinsList exact path="/" />
                <BinsMain path="/bins/:binId" />
            </Switch>
        </App>
</BrowserRouter>

But thats not everything. You have to import BrowserRouter and Switch from 'react-router-dom' (install it first) instead of doing the other imports from 'react-router';

There was another minor thing that was not up to date and I had to figure it out. Can't remember now.

results.content:
To date, I've bought eight or nine of Stephen's courses; this is the first one I wouldn't recommend. This course description said it was last updated in 6/2017, and that sold me on it. Today is 6/20/17, and having completed 80% of the course, I can't help wondering what was updated!

This course might have been worthy of a 5-Star rating when it came out (Stephen's classes usually are) but it's dated now. When I'm devoting my time to learning a framework that's new to me, I want to be learning the latest/greatest that framework offers. Unfortunately, this course features old versions of React, React Router, and Meteor.

Stephen replaced the React Router and React Form section of his excellent Modern React and Redux course to provide updated direction. Too bad he hasn't done that here, too.

results.content:
I've done my share of working through online tutorials; this was the first one I actually paid for and it was by far the best tutorial I've worked with.

Great explanations, good speed (fast typing which I liked), repeating of certain patterns for better learning, structured naming conventions, big font sizes in the programming editor so you can keep a small window with the video open in the corner of your monitor and have your editor up in the background (so no switching between programms needed).

If I had to criticize one thing it would be that I would have liked it better if the sections were a little longer, more like 8-10 minutes instead of 4-6 minutes. I sometimes felt like there was an unnecessary break between two sections because they were about the same topic and I just wanted to go on but instead had to listen to a conclusion and an introduction again. But then again there are probably a lot of people who appreciate those breaks, so that's just something me personally didn't like.

So yeah, great, great tutorial! Thank you very much, Stephen! I'm working on a project right now (kinda like a Tinder clone for movie/series recommendations that is hooked onto a machine learning server) before going into my master thesis, and this tutorial got me prepped really well! Thanks!

results.content:
This is a really excellent course as an introduction to Meteor and React, that also touches on some intermediate topics along the way.

The course walks you through the creation of four separate web applications, each offering experience and knowledge in different topics, that build in complexity towards to end of the course. Unlike a lot of courses the projects don't seem contrived, and one could imagine creating them for a real client! (particularly the final one)

Stephen's teaching style is great. He is clear, articulate, and logically splits his videos into small, manageable, topic-based chunks that never exceed 10 minutes and average around 4-6 minutes.

On infrequent occasions Stephen makes mistakes which he obviously made the conscious decision to leave in his videos. I personally like this approach for a couple of reasons: firstly, it shows that even experienced developers make mistakes, and secondly, it outlines common pitfalls one may encounter - which can aid in debugging them faster!

Ultimately I am very pleased with this course. It was absolutely worth the money in my view. If you are interested in Meteor and React then I thoroughly recommend it. This is coming from someone who had basic exposure to both technologies but wanted a more solid understanding.

results.content:
There were several points in the course where you thought that viewers might get bored with the "Import React" boilerplate. But I actually appreciate that you took the time to drive that point in. Imports and exports (at least the ES6 way) are new to JS and Meteor development and your course helped me to feel comfortable with their place in this new development workflow. 

I would HIGHLY recommend this course! Not only is it a good way to learn how to use React in Meteor (1.3, mind you!) but you start to get how back-end agnostic the React framework is, so it's really a good course for learning React by itself. I feel ready to develop production apps absolutely after watching this course!

I would have liked to see a section where you use flux or redux to manage state, simply because it's something that most apps end up using and it would be nice to know. That, however, does not take away from the value this course provides and it does provide A LOT! 

Thank You!

results.content:
Got into Meteor a while ago and let it slide again. Even back in it's early days people where very excited about combining Meteor with React. Never quite understood why as Blaze, the onboard template engine, works just fine. This course gave me some ideas on why it might be a good idea.

I like the example based approach. The course starts with a React only application using Meteor only as a development and server platform. This isn't a bad approach given that meteor could be used to turn a more or less pure React app into a mobile app.

The final example is a big one highlighting some of the strengths of Meteor. It starts with the integration of Blaze Templates into React which is indeed interesting. Data Publications and Subscriptions as well as Collection Methods are explained and a multi user system with sharing is added. Not bad for a course example.

Sadly the last example is out of date regarding the react-router package. A whole block of excercises (90 ~ 98 or so) is out of date and you need to dig into the Q&A to get it right. Luckily all seems to be there. There are also some deprication warnings. Check Q&A on those. Explainations are there.

For me the course was a little too slow. Videos are short and always start with "this is what we did last time" and end with "this is what we do next time". This starts to become really annoying as I know full well what I did 5 minutes ago and I really just want to get a larger chunk of the application done before moving on to another video.

Some videos are all about diagrams and explanations on how the dataflow works. Not too bad, but again I'd have preferred them to be pushed out of the way in one long video or being marked as skippable for those who get it.

What's hugely missing in this course is more about Meteor's abilities. Like how to build a mobile app. It's really simple but there's not even a mention of that ability. Also there's no explanation of Blaze and why React would be a better choice. Meteor packaging isn't mentioned either. Last but not least, no word about rolling out the application. How do I deploy it?

It's a great course to understand the mix of Meteor and React. To me it as the first contact with React. Not sure if I really want to use it yet but it's interesting to know about it's abilities. Meteor could have been handled in a bit more depth.

For those who'd like to get to grips with Meteor only it might not be the best choice. For React/Meteor it's obviously great and I'd recommend it. Since I learned quite a bit and am back in the Meteor boat after a long break I'm happy to reward 4 stars. What killed the 5th was the short video length, missing info on what's around Meteor and the slight out of date feel to it.

results.content:
Very thorough. Only a few gotchas that are not explained well, such as why he is using "npm install" instead of "meteor npm install" and not explaining the purpose of check/Match instead of using a simple if/else statement inside Meteor.methods. But overall, a very comprehensive introduction to Meteor using React.


Very much appreciated was the introduction to WebApp middleware to redirect on the server without rendering client-side, and how to use Meteor's built-in Blaze template authentication from within React components.


Lastly, I would like to see some tutorials on how to debug Meteor code beyond the obvious exception errors and console.log() outputs. Can you put in breakpoints, step-through code? How do you use the React Developer Tools? How do you create automated tests to insure you don't break your code when developing new functionality? Etc. These could potentially be addressed in a separate advanced course.

results.content:
Done with the first 16 or so lessons so far. Clean and detailed explanations, nice mockups. I have a quite solid programming background so I'm watching it 1.5-2x speed depending on the content otherwise it would be a bit slow for me but I suppose this is good news for someone new to JavaScript.

UPDATE: I've completed the course. I definitely recommend this for those who are new to Meteor and/or React and ES6. I knew Meteor before but I've learned a lot about React and ES6.

Some room for improvement: A little bit more about some typical mistakes and their consequences would be nice. Like 'What happens is if write this.onButtonClick().bind(this) instead of this.onButtonClick.bind(this)?' and the answer is: a very cryptic error message which is hard to debug :)

Also the GitHud repo branch numbering is off by a few (not a big deal, the branch name is good)

Thank you for this course!

results.content:
Definitely targeted at users unfamiliar with JavaScript, so it's a bit slow at times. Nevertheless he is a great teacher and even as an advanced JS Developer I am learning new stuff. I haven't used React at all yet and after the first two sections I already feel quite advanced. Can't wait to see the meteor part (as this is the part I signed up for most)

Edit: 
Alright, after completing it, I feel confident in my overall understanding of Meteor and React. At times the tutorials were a bit slow as I mentioned before, but overall I feel like they covered basically every important aspect of the frameworks.
A few more thoughts: You had a part covering the security, but later did not really keep it through. The final project is quite insecure. I can simply call Meteor.call('bins.remove', {}) and every users bins will be removed. Maybe a small notice would be appropriate since that's the number one threat for all web projects.

results.content:
My only complaints are that the explanations about React and Meteor could be more thorough and sometimes the narration is a little repetitive and a little too layman. 

Otherwise, this course is a great way to test the waters and see whether using React and Meteor will be for you. The apps that you'll build in this course each serve a specific purpose in teaching you fundamental skills in using Meteor and React, and by the end of it, you'll feel much more confident when you attempt to try and build an app on your own.

results.content:
Prior to taking this course, I completed Stephen's "Modern React with Redux" course, I completed the official Meteor tutorial, and I read the official Meteor Guide. This course has done a good job of bridging the gaps left by the official Meteor Guide, which is somewhat necessarily compartmentalized. Additionally, the official Meteor documents are still quite biased toward Blaze templating, and this course provides a better introduction of how to marry React and Meteor.

Stephen has put together and presents several diagrams and mockups that are very helpful - especially his diagrams related to handling data and Meteor's Optimistic UI. The final project was fantastic, albeit somewhat incomplete at this point, but still really great for outlining the main aspects of how a real app built with React and Meteor might come together. However, I did end up with a bug that I never quite figured out around video #96 or so (something to do with markdown) and I ended up just watching the last few videos instead of following along.

I would have loved if this course had followed a TDD approach, but that might be a whole other course in itself. After this course, before I can get started on an app, I'll still need to learn a lot more about testing, collection relationships, and component class inheritance. Perhaps these topics are covered in Stephen's Advanced React and Redux Course...
results.content_html:
Prior to taking this course, I completed Stephen's "Modern React with Redux" course, I completed the official Meteor tutorial, and I read the official Meteor Guide. This course has done a good job of bridging the gaps left by the official Meteor Guide, which is somewhat necessarily compartmentalized. Additionally, the official Meteor documents are still quite biased toward Blaze templating, and this course provides a better introduction of how to marry React and Meteor.

Stephen has put together and presents several diagrams and mockups that are very helpful - especially his diagrams related to handling data and Meteor's Optimistic UI. The final project was fantastic, albeit somewhat incomplete at this point, but still really great for outlining the main aspects of how a real app built with React and Meteor might come together. However, I did end up with a bug that I never quite figured out around video #96 or so (something to do with markdown) and I ended up just watching the last few videos instead of following along.

I would have loved if this course had followed a TDD approach, but that might be a whole other course in itself. After this course, before I can get started on an app, I'll still need to learn a lot more about testing, collection relationships, and component class inheritance. Perhaps these topics are covered in Stephen's Advanced React and Redux Course...

results.content: I have enjoyed several of Stephen Grider's courses.  He is by far the best instructor on Udemy I have come across.  He winds Meteor and React into worthwhile apps, and the pace and content of the course makes it easy for anyone to follow along.

results.content: Material is presented very clearly. I really like that he starts with mockups and shows how to break it into components. Then, rather than just downloading some boilerplate - he starts with an empty project and shows (time and time again) all the necessary pieces to get the desired functionality. After watching many other tutorials, this is the only one that really explained all the moving parts and how (and why) they interact. The one thing I felt was missing was form validation - an essential piece of any application, but I'm sure I can find documentation on it and now I'll understand what I'm looking at. This was a great way to get started!
